title: The Fall of Jericho
shortSummary: Joshua 6 recounts the miraculous conquest of Jericho by the Israelites under Joshua’s leadership, following God’s specific instructions. The chapter highlights God’s power to deliver His people when they obey His commands and marks a pivotal moment in Israel’s possession of the Promised Land.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israel's conquest of Canaan under Joshua's leadership

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who commands the people to follow God's instructions in the siege and capture of Jericho.

keyCharacters.name: Rahab
keyCharacters.description: A Canaanite woman in Jericho who hides Israelite spies and is spared during the city's destruction because of her faith and obedience.

keyCharacters.name: The Seven Priests
keyCharacters.description: Priests who carry the Ark of the Covenant and blow rams' horns as part of the divine strategy to bring down Jericho’s walls.

keyCharacters.name: The King of Jericho
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Jericho who is defeated as God delivers the city into Israel’s hands.

definitions.definition: The sacred chest representing God's presence among Israel, carried by priests during the march around Jericho.
A term meaning devoted to destruction for God, designating that the city and its contents were to be destroyed as an offering to Him.
A trumpet made from a ram’s horn used in religious ceremonies and warfare to signal and proclaim God’s intervention.
The act of marching around the city’s walls as commanded by God, symbolizing obedience and trust in His plan.

outline.heading: God’s Promise and Instructions for the Siege
outline.description: God assures Joshua that Jericho and its king are given into Israel’s hand and commands a unique strategy involving marching around the city and blowing trumpets, emphasizing faith and obedience.

outline.heading: The Daily March Around Jericho
outline.description: Joshua organizes the people and priests to carry out God’s instructions, marching once around the city for six days in silence, demonstrating disciplined obedience.

outline.heading: The Seventh Day and the Fall of Jericho
outline.description: On the seventh day, the Israelites march seven times around Jericho, then shout at Joshua’s command, causing the city walls to collapse miraculously, allowing Israel to capture the city.

outline.heading: Rahab’s Deliverance and the Destruction of Jericho
outline.description: Rahab and her family are spared because of her faith and protection of the spies, while the city is burned and all else destroyed, fulfilling God’s judgment and promise.

outline.heading: Joshua’s Curse and God’s Favor
outline.description: Joshua pronounces a curse on anyone who would rebuild Jericho, and the chapter closes by affirming God’s presence with Joshua and his growing fame throughout the land.

application: Trust God’s instructions even when they seem unconventional, knowing His ways lead to victory.
Obedience to God’s commands is essential for experiencing His power and blessings in our lives.
Have faith like Rahab, who acted on God’s promises and was spared because of her belief and courage.
Recognize God’s sovereignty in all battles and give Him glory for every victory.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Joshua, See, I have given into thine hand Jericho, and the king thereof, and the mighty men of valour.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s sovereign promise of victory, assuring Joshua that the conquest is divinely secured.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that when they make a long blast with the ram's horn, and when ye hear the sound of the trumpet, all the people shall shout with a great shout; and the wall of the city shall fall down flat, and the people shall ascend up every man straight before him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the miraculous power of God to bring down strongholds when His people obey and trust Him.

keyVerses.text: So the people shouted when the priests blew with the trumpets: and it came to pass, when the people heard the sound of the trumpet, and the people shouted with a great shout, that the wall fell down flat, so that the people went up into the city, every man straight before him, and they took the city.
keyVerses.significance: This verse records the fulfillment of God’s promise through obedient faith, demonstrating His power to deliver.

keyVerses.text: So the LORD was with Joshua; and his fame was noised throughout all the country.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms God’s continued presence with Joshua, validating his leadership and the success of Israel’s conquest.
